dialog.text: Why do I keep blaming others when I get hurt?
dialog.instructions: young boy voice, unsure, breathy, slight tremor; curious, soft pace

dialog.text: Because blame is a loud armor—easier to wear than feel the soft wound beneath.
dialog.instructions: calm, deep, shadowy; wise and gentle, slow cadence

dialog.text: But blaming makes me feel stronger. Isn't that better than feeling weak?
dialog.instructions: defensive, quick delivery, searching for reassurance

dialog.text: It may feel like strength, but it's borrowed. Blame points outward; healing asks you to point inward.
dialog.instructions: patient, steady, slightly warm; clear and grounding

dialog.text: How do I turn inward without falling apart?
Begin small. Name the feeling under your blame—shame, fear, loneliness. Speak it, then breathe into it.
dialog.instructions: gentle coach tone, encouraging, slower than before

dialog.text: Okay... I felt abandoned. Saying it makes my chest ache.
dialog.instructions: vulnerable, exhale between words, honest; soft and intimate

dialog.text: That's the place to stay. Breathe into the ache. Welcome it like a guest instead of exiling it with blame.
dialog.instructions: compassionate, warm, soothing; pause between sentences

dialog.text: When I welcome it, I see I wanted safety—not to punish someone.
dialog.instructions: soft revelation, quieter, a spark of relief

dialog.text: Exactly. Blame was a rumor of protection. Replace it with responsibility: 'I was hurt, I will care for myself.' That choice returns your power.
dialog.instructions: reassuring, hopeful, steady; slight uplift at the end

dialog.text: So letting go of blame heals the wound and the relationships tied to it?
dialog.instructions: hopeful, curious, leaning forward in voice

dialog.text: Yes. When you stop weaponizing pain, you open space for truth, repair, and connection. Your shadow isn't an enemy—it's a teacher asking for tenderness.
dialog.instructions: luminous, calm, wise; gentle crescendo on 'tenderness'

dialog.text: I'll try—starting by asking what I really felt the last time I blamed someone.
dialog.instructions: determined, small smile in voice, grounded

dialog.text: Try that now. Reflect on one recent moment you blamed someone—what feeling lived beneath it? Share your insight in the comments, or sit with it for five slow breaths. Healing begins the moment blame loosens its grip.
dialog.instructions: inviting, warm, slow; clear call-to-action, gentle urgency
